rue Saint-Jacques / place Saint-Henri[http://www.stm.info/English/metro/Place-Saint-Henri.pdf Place-Saint-Henri Station Neighbourhood Map] |}} '''Place-Saint-Henri''' is a [[metro station|station]] on the [[Line 2 Orange (Montreal Metro)|Orange Line]] of the [[Montreal Metro]] [[Rapid transit|rapid transit system]], operated by the [[SociÃ©tÃ© de transport de MontrÃ©al]] (STM). It is located in the [[Saint-Henri]] area of the borough of [[Le Sud-Ouest]] in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], [[Canada]] [http://www.stm.info/English/metro/a-m46.htm Place-Saint-Henri Metro Station]. The station opened on April 28, 1980, as the western terminus of the first extension of the orange line. It thus took over from [[Bonaventure (Montreal Metro)|Bonaventure]] station as terminus, and remained so until the extension to [[Snowdon (Montreal Metro)|Snowdon]] in 1981. == Overview == The metro station is a normal [[side platform]] station, connected by long [[Stairway|stairwells]] to a large [[Mezzanine (architecture)|mezzanine]]. The station has three accesses; one is a conventional access within a bus loop, while the other two are open-air [[Stairway|staircases]] linked to an underground [[Tunnel|gallery]] connected to the mezzanine. These make Place-Saint-Henri one of the only three stations in Montreal to have uncovered accesses (with Bonaventure and [[Square-Victoria (Montreal Metro)|Square-Victoria]] stations). The station was designed by [[Julien HÃ©bert]] and Jean-Louis Lalonde. It originally contained two [[Work of art|artwork]]s: a [[mural]] by HÃ©bert in the mezzanine, entitled ''[[Bonheur d'occasion]]'', featuring the title of the famous book by [[Gabrielle Roy]] (in English called ''The Tin Flute''), set in the neighbourhood; and a motorized mobile sculpture by [[Jacques de Tonnancour]] suspended in the mezzanine and over the platforms. A statue of [[Jacques Cartier]] by [[Joseph-Arthur Vincent]], created in 1896, was moved to the station and placed in a light shaft over the CÃ´te-Vertu platform. It had formerly crowned a fountain in a nearby park, but was removed, moved to the station, and replaced with a copy after having crumbled due to exposure. ==Origin of the name== This station is named for place Saint-Henri, a short street and public square between [[Saint-Jacques Street|rue Saint-Jacques]] and [[Notre-Dame Street|rue Notre-Dame]].
